description:
Human papillomavirus 5 (HPV5) is a member of the Papillomaviridae family, a group of non-enveloped, double-stranded DNA viruses that primarily infect the skin and mucous membranes of humans. HPV5 is classified as a member of the beta-papillomavirus genus, which is associated with the development of benign skin lesions and a small subset of non-melanoma skin cancers.

HPV5 is commonly found in individuals with epidermodysplasia verruciformis (EV), a rare genetic disorder characterized by an increased susceptibility to persistent infection with specific HPV types, including HPV5. Individuals with EV are at an elevated risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma of the skin, and HPV5 has been detected in a significant proportion of these skin cancers.

The genome of HPV5 consists of approximately 8,000 base pairs and encodes various proteins involved in viral replication, transcription, and the modulation of host cell functions. The virus primarily infects the basal layer of the epidermis and can establish a persistent, latent infection within the host cells. HPV5 has been shown to contribute to the development of skin cancer through its ability to interfere with cellular pathways that regulate cell growth and differentiation, as well as its potential to induce genomic instability.

Understanding the biology and epidemiology of HPV5 is important for the development of targeted diagnostic and preventive strategies, particularly for individuals with EV and other high-risk populations.
